div.head: Preface.
div.p:
In the expressed opinions of all men of indubitable
refinement, and of comprehensive intellect, Poetry has ever
been accounted a high and sacred thing. Imapassioning
the master spirits of all ages, those of a merely mechanical
order excepted, it has been crowned by their united au-
thority with the application og the Divine Art. Nor has
this empyreal distinction been unworthily accorded to an
Attainment which is the result of an indwelling love of
Beauty and Truth in their essence, and which constitutes
in Man an affinity with the Seraph. Whatever is con-
-stituent in a disposition to natural piety, and all that is
elemental in human aptitude for a state of complete intel-
-lectual liberty, are equally as essential to the full growth
and maturity of poetic genius, and of the critical capacity
by which its finer creations can be duly appreciated and
enjoyed. Mere worldlings indeed, may be prone to
despise the mental riches of the Muse, and common-place
philosophers to confine, theoretically, the influences dis-
-posing to poetic feeling within the narrow boundaries of
their own spiritual vision; but the more gifted children
of Taste know on the contrary, that those are amongst
the most valuable legacies of the Past, and that these have being in all that is sublime and beautiful in the
Universe, to replenish it as a whole with a subtler and
more exquisite unity of Love. And thus boundlessly
prevalent, these influences are but ingathered as to a centre
by the sovereign imagination of the Poet; not so much
for self-enjoyment, as again to be given forth in
immortal verse, condensed and melodised, and genial
with the fertility of passion; -- and it is only upon their
having passed through this process, that they are perfected
in the power of causing the hard heart of the listening
world to gush over with unwonted bounty -- even as
the living waters were elicited from the rock by the stroke
of Moses's rod.

Still I am painfully aware that amongst the
most virtuous portions of educated society, there exists
at present a strong pre-possession in disfavor of poetry.
I do not, however, infer from this, that there is any vital
decay of imaginative taste amongst these the highest
order of readers. On the contrary, I believe, that in such
circles, the ideal requirements of our nature, poetical
as well as musical and pictorial, are in constant
pace with the progress of real refinement; and that
the disrelish above mentioned, is owing chiefly, if not
solely, to the evil uses to which compositions in this kind.
have been prostituted by certain modern Writers of great
but depraved genius. But deeply as the Poetic Muse may
have been thus sinned against, it yet behoves the refined
and philosophic rightly to distinguish between her proper
tendencies, and the moral alloy with which these have always
been more or less darkened by the corruptions of her
children. Her true vocation is at once to quicken,
exalt and purify, our nobler and more exquisite passions;
and by informing the imagination with wisdom=sug=
-gesting beauty, both to enlarge and recompense our
capacities of pathetic feeling and intellectual en=
-joyment: and further, in social and national regards,
to illustrate whatever is virtuous in design, and
-glorify all that is noble in action; taking occasion
-also, from time to time, to pour the lightning of her
-holy indignation upon every thing that is mean and
-cowardly in the people, or tyrannical and corrupt in
their rulers.

In another and more fanciful view of the
nature and office of Poesie, her creations may be said to
stand in such relation to human life as dreams do to
the state of slumber. When the tone of this state is healthy,
these are cheerful, full of promise, beautifully fantastic.
When diseased, on the contrary, they are boding, full of
horror, monstrously incongruous. So is it with the creations
of the Muse, according as the individual minds in which
these are produced, and the social soil on which they are
intended to operate, are morally healthy or otherwise. --
And to continue the analogy in the better part of its
agreement, her winged things of Love are also, in
their forward flight, -- like dreams, or what we may
suppose of dreams, -- sometimes prophetic. Like
these too, in a salubrious sphere, they beautify the
common, and transmute the terrible into the lovely.
They convert the frowns of misfortune, and the litter
glances of enmity, into smiles of benevolence, and tears
of reconciliation. They annihilate distance as with
the "wings of the Morning", and captivity as with the
the starry liberties of the Universe. In fine, they recall
the past, enchant the present, and realise the future; --
restore the lost, renew the changed, enrich the poor, and
reunite the living and the dead. And without them, -- that
is, a Polite Literature, -- society is a mere machine for
the production and consumption of food, comfortably
oiled at the joints and wrapped in lamb's wool.

With regard to the outcry which has ever
obtained more or less amongst certain religious
bodies against all profane fiction, and especially if
of a passionate cast, it should be observed, that the
morality of Poetry, like that of all other influences
affecting human conduct, is precisely correspondent to
the nature of its cause. Of poetry of a healthy kind,
the moral effect upon its readers will be healthy also.
It is objected, for instance, that it addresses itself chiefly
to the passions. But to this, in its general scope, the
general truth of things appends a sufficient answer.
The passions are, and ever will be, the elements of
human life, and Morality (properly so called) is nothing
more than the systematised experience of Reason and
Imagination, in joint effort, to secure the best results
from the sympathetic and antipathetic activity of these.
They constitute our strength as well as our weakness. They
beautify as well as deform our character, and whatever
tends to dwarf or perish, or more than wisely direct
them, tends so far to vitiate it. And if this be true,
and I believe there can be little rational doubt of it,
the thousand and onereligious objections to the moral
influence of Poetry, as such, will eventually be current
only amongst the ignorant congregations of obscure
conventicles, and philosophically respectable in the eyes
of puritan divines and common-place essayists.
Of my own poetry, if I might judge of its moral
effect upon others from its moral influence upon
myself, I should opine that it will operate
healthily, and chiefly for good! I have never

div.head: To the Lyre of Australia. o

lg.l: Lyre of my Country, remains it for me
From the charm-muttering Savage's rude-beating hand,
To snatch thee; that so thy wild numbers may be
No longer but writ on the winds of the Land?
And though he who thy chords now would master, may never
Evince in his verse all their rapture of tone,
Yet -- yet should Australia smile on the endeavour,
The glory so won by the Bard were her own.
Wild sounding Lyre of the South, could I vie
With a Burns in the strength of his patriot fire,
O then I would raise thee in glory on high --
The guardian of Beauty, of Valor the sire!
And could I but hope that, as music assuages
When heard in the pause of the gale sweeping o'er,
My Country should list in the rush of her ages,
To this Song, sounding onward, -- I'd covet no more.
With her green forest round me, above her blue sky,
I lap in thy measures some national dream;
And I find that our songs, though unstudied, are high,
When the glory of Future Australia's the theme:
And even thy Lay, to her sons and her daughters,
Should breathe of the Land where the evergreen grows --
To men's souls like the strong wind that swelleth the waters,
To the heart like a spring breeze that opens the rose.*

p.note:
This address to the Lyre of Australia was written in
my teens -- say, twelve years ago. But, alas! neither then
nor since did my Country deign to award one smile of
encouragement to the endeavours of her Poet. Her best
and only gifts to him have been hunger and rags. Nay,
my literary enemies and disparagers all along, have
been mostly countrymen. In short, my name and fame
up to this moment, except as bye words in the mean
mouths of such defamers and detractors, are utterly blanks
in their day and generation; -- and I conclude therefore,
that either I am unworthy of my country and country=
-men, or my countrymen are unworthy of it and me.
Time will ratify this conclusion one way or the other --
and to Time I refer it accordingly C.H.
1847.

div.p: (Rude association)

When these Rhymes were written, my outward circumstances
were much better than at the time of my composing those
preceding them (the Poet.), yet inwardly I was even more
dissatisfied than then; For may years I was being obliged to associate daily with persons whose natures could value nothing in mine
that I valued myself; whose souls indeed had no faith for
anything in God's glorious Universe that was not, in
their own vile phrase, "mone worth." Thus circumstances, when I reflected what "miserable men" almost all our Poets
had ever been through the unfitness of similar compulsory
associations, I had nearly armed myself in the resolutions
of destroying as far as I could, all poetical record of my
being: and of living mentally apart for the
remainder of my life, dying eventually, like the wolf, in
silence. But as time slid on, I gradually thought and felt
myself out of this bitterness of love -- for such it was; love of the
Beautiful, crushed into bitterness by the burthen of its own
incommunicable wealth. This analysis of feeling may be
sneered at by the prosaic, but a "fit audiance though few" will
understand it better, by virtue of a lovelier experience.C.H.

lg.l: A Trooper of France, in desperate need,
Had struggled from under his dying steed,
Where Egypt's pyramids appeared;
While on his black war horse, the Turk
Who had borne him down, to finish his work,
back wheelingly careered.
aking his resolute stand
Foot deep in his charger's blood,
The Soldier of Christendom, sword in hand,
That gleamily out pointing, showed
Like the lightning tongue of a setting cloud,
His Foe awaiting stood.
Urged into whirlwind speed,
On -- on with a scattering tail,
Like the hurrying thunder bolts smocky trail!
On -- on with a streaming mane,
Like the foremost racks of a hurricane!
On came the Arab steed.
Then passed with a vengeful clash
Of blades, and a lunging downward crash,
The imminent shock!
And when its cloud of dust upthrown
Cleared off, there stood that Trooper alone,
Firm as a rock!
But two steeds and a Moslem in death lay still,
And a kite of the Desert that came flop flop
In heavy flight from a pyramid's top,
In a merry mood
At the scent of blood,
Was circling o'er and screaming shrill.*

p.note:
I found the subject of these Rhymes in some account
(I know not whose) of the French acchievements in Egypt,
under the mighty murderer, Napoleon. thought the
incident capable of being elaborated into a powerful
poetical picture, and siezed upon it accordingly: but
having done so, I must record against it the facts, that I consider Bonaparte's invasion of the East
was not simply but monstrously unwarrantable; and
that I have but little admiration, under any circum=
-stances, for mere military heroism. What hadhave Truth
and Human Good to do with the sword? What can it
prove, of used offensively, but that men are sometimes worse
than wild beasts? and what, even when employed in the
defensive, but that murder, violence, and robbery are
sometimes only to be repelled by their own inhuman means?
What is there in mere bravery worthy of engaging our admiration?
The bull-dog is brave. What is there in mere distructiveness
worthy of commanding our emulation? The tiger is
eminently distructive. If we must needs glorify our in=
-dividualities, let it , in the name of sanity,be for such
things as lift us above, not such as ally us to the brutes.
Still I would not be misunderstood. I esteem rational
valor a prime social virtue; and think that they who
would not uphold their Country's liberties at the cost
of life, were unworthy even of that base existence for
which, in thatsuch case, these would be forfieted. All I
would be understood to mean, is, that if in the
national systems of the world now obtaining, war is occasion=
-ally inevitable, still woe be to them by whom war
cometh.

lg.l: Many a weary day and night
Have ta'en their unregretted flight,
Dawned many a hopeless morrow,
Since this wild wreath 'mid scenes afar,
I wove in joy and sorrow.
And long it was ere I could deem
That the so gratefully glowing star
Of Morning Love did only beam
To gild a morning dream.
But so it was: although she'd die,
The Maiden vowed, if Fate our lot
Cast separate; nor in vows was I
Behind her a single jot!
But Fate, in the vile shape of pelf,
At length between us thrust herself,
And yet (however strange to tell)
We both lived on -- and -- to get well.
Alas! a tear is in mine eye,
To think our very truth was -- what?
At best -- A golden lie!
And hence, although I will it not,
The Real is battling from my head
All -- all the dear Romance that shed
O'er other days and nights
Such heart-bewitching lights;
And Caution dinning me the while,
With -- Have a care of Beauty's smile;
For though a thing so rosy-rich
And tender, 'tis the stuff of which
Is woven Passion's painful thrall.
Yes, of the Love that left me lonely,
Such, Lady, is the sequel only,
And such the profit all!
And for the days that bore it by
These lines are -- one long written Sigh;
Wherewith (so singular is my grief)
In earnest half and half in jest,
Mine heart I banter for relief

lg.l: How few through Memory's dreamy scope,
However resolute of hope,
Can view the backward scene where first
Their Youth rejoiced, forever crost,
And not bewail, like Adam erst,
The Eden he hadthey have lost!
Nor feel, alas, with it compared,
The present but a lengthening wild,
Whereon young Passion never fared,
Young Beauty never smiled!
Yet 'tis a melancholy pleasure,
To sit by moon-struck Memory's side,
And list her wild lyre oft remeasure
The story of our youthful pride!
Hours recalling all whitely rife
With emotions lavished wide
Through the Garden of our Life
Ere all its spring-time roses died!
And like those splendors, when the Sun
Remits in his decline from weaving
A robe of beauty for the Ev'ning,
Fancy's Elysiums, one by one,
Had paled away as the long Night came on.

div.head: The Glen of the Whiteman's Grave.

lg.l: I had well-nigh fared through a summer day
O'er rugged mountains that round me lay,
Far as a wonder-keen eye could see,
Range after range, like a shoreless sea
Of mighty in breakers! But some held sway
Over the rest as 'twere, -- towering away,
Alone in their greatness like rival Kings,
High as soar the eagle's wings --
High as the fleecy clouds that play
In the open face of a sunny day.
Such had been my course -- and when
The day was well-nigh ended,
Into a deep and dusky Glen
The mountain track descended:
A gloomy Glen that far was seen
Winding hugely on between
Two craggy rampires, stained in face
With many a tempest's wrath --
Hugely on, like a time-hewn path
For the Genius wild of so wild a place.
In this melancholy Glen
Far my feet had fared not, when
In the pathway I might see,
Right against me as I came,
Carved in the bark of a grand old Tree,
A fatal fortuned Name.
'Twas the name of a murdered Man, and I
Many a time by the bush-fire side,
Had heard his story with a sigh,
And a boding look o'er the wilderness wide;
And therefore, turned me from the road
With a sympathetic load
At heart, and with rueful face,
To find his Grave in that lonely place.
That evening! never knew I one
More solemn-browed. The great round Sun,
O'er the lit summits crowding vast
Against the west, was sinking fast.
A few white clouds alone were seen
To stir the vault of Heaven's serene,
As tangled ivy-looks might wave
From the ceiling dim of some mighty Cave.
A gust, at measured intervals,
Fell o'er the nearer mountain walls
And then passed off, Or pausedlingred here and there to pine
Its own dirge in the in the top of the turpentine;
As with a sound like athe motion of snakes
Rustled away through the rounding brakes.
And once a dusky eagle came
In solemn travel o'er the the same --
Steadily straight, as from afar
Came o'er, -- but soon the airy jar
Of his huge wings, in faint decrease,
Faded beyond thine -- and all was peace.
And now the sought for Grave I found. --
Against me stretched, its lonely mound
Was darkly seen, and by degrees,
In the shadows therebroken shade of the silent trees; --
Darkly -- save as as the last long blade
Of the setting sun for a moment played

l.add: A few dun cloudlets only were
Seen in the vault of heaven to stir
As ivy-like might wave
From the marble root of mighty cave

lg.l: O'er it, and then backward ran;
As hope's last flickering gleam might fade
From the face of a doomed man.
One only tuft of grass did wave
Above that sterile desert Grave,
Bestrewn with leaves and withering sprays;
And only one blue flower did gaze
Timidly up, as near I trod,
From between the dry lips of a broken clod.
O 'twas a desolate, dreary thing,
That Grave, in the else-green lap of Spring!
As I looked on it then through a starting tear,
And the feeling -- Alas! for the Sleeper here!
I would not -- I would not one human child
Of the earth should be laid in a Grave so wild.
Strange was the sympathy I felt
TowrdsFor the lonely dead, as now I knelt
Down by his grave, and musefully drew
His Image on that evil day
When there first coming on the view
Of felons bent to slay!
A visionary Youth, methought,
On he came, all wonder-wrought
With the dreary grandeur there;
Which oft his memory would compare,
For contrast, with the rural joy
Of scenes in merry England, where
He had wandered when a boy; --
Scenes vocal then with voices gay
Of many a loved one -- far away.
My spirit, searching then and keen,
Passed o'er the isle-thronged seas between
The Antipodes, and onward o'er
The navy-laden waves that roar
Against the coast of England, -- there.
To seek a sire of the same name,
With her, that doomed Youth who bare,
A sorrow-pallid dame.
I figured them both old and grey,
And bent with mourning many a day --
Mourning hopelessly for One
Their age had cherished, and in whom,
Even through the sacred tie of son,
They had seen again their own young bloom:
But they dreamt not, as they blest him then,
Of a lonely Grave in a gloomy Glen,
Thought I, recurring to its gloom;
Even this, whereon, you clod between,
The nameless flower of a nameless scene
Thus rears its solitary head;
And where a kindred Creature's tread
Comes seldom -- comes but to wake a cry
Of wonder in the wild-dog's lair,
The only dwellingabode of the quick; and where,
Even the Black seldom ventures nigh,
Never dares to halt: but, hushing their noise,
He points out as he comes to his cowering boys,
The Whiteman's Grave! -- then hurries by.
And thinking thus of him who slept
There, and of them who even then
Might mourn that Sleeper of the Glen,
A brother's sorrow o'er me crept;
And seeing I might vainly try
To keep mine eyelids longer dry,
I sat me by the Grave -- and wept!
Wept, until settling up the Glen,
The night forbad me more delay;
And bettered was my spirit when
I sped at length away.
O sacred Sympathy! best mate
Of Grief, with them go mourn
Yes; 'tis a melancholy sweet!
And athus let Memory oft repeat
Life's first tale, that to the core
Re-Tempered by such generous lore,
Our sterning spirits, as 'tis meet,

May pity the cold world -- the world we trust no
more.*

div.note:
There is nothing which, to my mind, establishes the fact our
spirituality more incontestably than that delicate Sense of the
Past which is the expression of these Rhymes: that spread of
our feelings, as it were, over half a life, to be inagthered, upon
occasion, to their centre, the soul, like the tracery of a gossamer.
Still in connexion with this soul-born faculty there is often.
much pain, arising from the consciousness of our having
become worse; -- less generous, less devotional, less loving
(in an unselfish sense). Alas! in the great majority of cases,
to have become elderly is to have made entire shipwreck of
the Spiritual! To have lived fifty years is almost inevita=
-bly to have arrived at that bad pass in which the Ma=
=terial is alone sought after and believed in! Strange, that the
more we have experience of the precarious and unsatisfact=
-ory nature of all merely earthly things, that we should
yet grow to them more and more! That is the further
we travel heavenward, our spirits, once so erect
like our boides, should contract like these, more and more
of a tendency to stoop dustward! But such is the case,
and whence is it? Mainly from the influence of a corrupt
civilization, the wisdom of which is only and continually of the
earth, earthy; and which (so insiduous is it) the generosity
of youth can alone counteract for the time -- and even for thus
long in but a very few individuals.The great lump of humanity
is destitute even of this --
it is bred out of it. But there are better times coming.C.H.

div.head: On the Death of Shelley.

lg.l: Fit shroud for Thee
Was the eternal sea!
Fit dirge the tempest's slave-alarming roll!
For fetterless in life was still
The genius of thy will,
And loud the godlike thunder of thy fearless soul!
Yet tell me, Spirit bright,
Was Fate not sad for thee?
That day, veiled not the Sun his light
When rollinh over Italic?
Paled not the conscious Moon, that night,
When gazing on the fatal Sea?
Feeling for once the eclipsive might
Of Death's disastrous spell?
Resolve me -- for from under them
Was never reft away a richer -- purer gem!
O sayNever -- fornever in their day and night
Did Ruin never wroughtwork before such spite --
Never triumphed over aught they loved so well!
Thus, looking from an Austral mountain cone,
A Minstrel of that region rude
Poured for the Dead his questioning moan,
Even as then, at times,
Gushed from his heart the unmeasured rhymes,
And silent then, and listening stood:
But all unwanswered was the strain!
Only that in like melancholy mood,
Echo, afar, its questions asked again;
And soon alone the mirth
Was heard of Nature's murmurous broods,
Up coming from the streamy plain
And from the dusky moods;
While down upon the gladdened earth
The sun in so cloudless glory shone,
And the young moon, beyond the main,
Sate smiling on her silver throne.
Folding his tremulous fingers hard
For passionate complaint, the Bard
Resumed his mournful Lay:
And -- Ah, so soon to fleet away
To silence ever dumb!
All in the noontide of his day --
With much to build within -- without to overcome!
This was the burthen of the cry
It wailed along:
When from a sphered and nameless Light
That, as it floated by,
Waned like the moon upon his sight,
A stilly Voice made sweet reply:
"Whom the Gods love die young!
Flowers blighted fall where weeds still thrive apace!
The battle is not always to the strong,
Nor to the swift the race!
But where the odours of the flowers remain,
Can these not give even to Regret,
At length, a soul of grace?
Nor vainly forth was the lost battle set,
Nor vainly urged the race,
Whence flow examples yet."
Yes, Poesie's anointed son,
Though thou didst tread the world as one
Proscribed by stars unkind;
While mitred Persecution dread
Raged -- an incarnate Fiend -- behind!
With Ignorance her slave abhorred!
And who, in mercy as they said,
With many a muttered mystic word,
And baneful glance upthrown,
Petitioned Heaven to rain its blackest judgment down
On thy devoted head!
Yes, though thus tried, most gentle one,
This was the meed for thee by Destiny designed:
That men to nobler motions born,
Should well atone their fathers' scorn,

By glorying in the fearless might of thy surpassing
mind.
Even so then, all was well,
Though brief -- too brief thy stay!
Thy Name remains, a strengthening spell
To all who, banding against Error rude,
Would do the unwilling world some good,
Nor idly pass away --
A vapour, nothing more, athwart the realm of day!
And though the heart and brain be food
For dustyhungry Death, where erst, -- a precious brood,
Like quires of Seraphs thy bright dreams did dwell,
What light around us these, remaining, fling!
For lovelier splendors never fell
In star-drops from Urania's wing!
And Freedom, in her promised age,

Shall constellate her spheres with glories from thy
page.
But hark! yet from her haunted cell
Built on that dubious brink of the Unknown,
Where Fraud and Fear and Phrensy dwell,
Superstition's sullen bell
Tolls thee to her deepest hell!
Blind Fury! can she think alone,

Bedimmed by many an error,
Should lossward at her bidding sink in terror? --
Lossward in penal terror!
Enough! -- Wherever Love and Grace

note.p:
To prevent my admiration of Shelley's poetical
genius and character, from being misinterpreted into a kindred
atheism, and yet, at the same time, to vindicate the right he
had, not only to worship at whatever shrine he chose, but also
to advocate whatever he believed true; I will append to this
Monody some remarks on what I consider a proper Liberty
of Speculative Opinion.

To begin: -- I believe in the existence of a God, the creator
and providential disposer of all things. Nothing, I appre=
=hend, could shake me from this belief, but am I therefore to
denounce the atheist, who in all social respects may be a far
better man than myself; seeing that many so believing ac=
=cording to the general notion, have been singular for the moral
beauty and purity of their lives? By such a course, what
do I do more than instigate him in turn to denounce his
denouncer till between us, Charity, -- that which should
be "all mankind's concern", -- is hunted from our homes?
If it be a damnable sin to disavow any established or
peculiar Idea of the Deity, upon the disavower's own
head be it at the tribunal of Heaven -- not here. But
what if his disavowal carry with it points of
disbelief as to the God-Ideas of every other man or set
of men in the world? He should be left perfectly free
notwithstanding, either to believe or disbelieve, since he
is fallible only in common with all other men; and openly
to state and reason upon his convictions either way, so
long as this be done in decent terms and without personal
intrusion. Out of blending contrariety harmony arises; and our moral differences should but constitute
the moral music of life. For Truth, though one in its essence, is manifold
in its attributes; and

perhaps no highly intellectual man is, or ever was, what

So much by the way, and now to the Apologue.

note.p:
The sticklers for stilts in poetry will be disposed to
to quarrel with this Effusion.I am sure of that. It wants all the false
pomp of big-worded inversion, and the iterant balance of
metres, plentifully besprinkled with exclamatory prettiness is,
which they consider proper to poetry, if not poetry itself.
But the fact is, Verse has no more right than Prose has to violate the
natural order of language than Prose has. Its license in
this respect extends, or should extend, no further than to
arrange it metrically; and a poetical style that trans-
-gresses this limit is so far vitious. In short, good poe-
-try is just good prose, as far as composition is con-
-cerned, measured into a linear or a paragraphical con-
-sonance. The Splendor of passion, and the picturesqness of expression ideal suggestive-
-ness, -which togetherall that constitutes its essential and distin-
-guishing spirit, are so far independent of these forms, or
of any arbitrary forms, as to declare them dispensable,
however exquisite in themselves. Nay, more. These
virtual qualities of poetry are often injured by the chains of metre, beyond all the compensation
derivable from their graces however golden. Still the
wild gait of the Muse must, and should be restricted
to a verbal and sentimental harmony; and few persons
can be less disposed to decry the genuine felicities of
numbers than myself, or more dispoed to be dissatisfied
with any poem in which there is a paucity of wildly
musical lines, flowing full on and cascading into
one another like natural waters -- not like Dutch dykes,
only varied by intersections at right angles. In the pe-
-culiar style of this very poem I put forth all the metrical
skill I was master of. But alas! the following stroke,
in which I flattered myself I had hit a nicety full on
the crown, has since been instanced to my face, as an un-
-pardonable negligence:

Tow'rds the lonely dead, as now I knelt

So much for the discrimination of finger-counting critics,

lg.l: I love Him so,
That though his face I ne'er might see,
In the assurance that he so loved me,
My happy heart would glow
With pulses sweeter than the sweetest be
That colder ones can know.
I love Him so,
That to my thought twere sweet to sleep
Even in death, believing he would keep,
With solemn steps and slow,
In sabbath memory my grave, and weep
For Her who slept below.
I love Him so,
That all desires when he is by,
Shrink even from the import of a sigh;
As flowers unseen that grow,
Being mute, must so remain; as in the sky
Are stars that none may know.*

note.p:
The This little Poem was the final product
of a long and patient study of the passion it treats
of, as manifested in the evident feelings and the whole under=
conduct of a most interesting young creature, whose
nature was at once ardent and secretive. Her love was
long her burthen, and I watched the manner of it, as
occasion offered, with an interest bordering on solicitude --
and had eventually the pleasure of seeing her the bride of
the Beloved. -- My brain akes, and my heart sickens,
when I contrast in memory the fortunes of my own
feelings with those of hers. Not because she is happy.
I do not envy her, I only pity myself. C.H.

lg.l: Thy fairy feet, thy sylphic waist,
And those twin innocents, as they
Fill up like doves whose nestward haste
Had flurried them; those lips that play
Apart so clovenly and rich;
Those pinky cheeks, and -- thou sweet Witch!
Those eyes, the loveliest in the world,
And that fair forehead, over curled
With tresses in their darkness bright,
Like darkness of a starry night,
And massing inward round a neck
Veined, but quitless of a speck,
And throatward full, for Melodies
Hived within like honey bees,
To store it with live sweetness; -- these
All fill me with such fond dismay,
That still, for looking though the more
In love, -- for Love I've less to say
Than when I looked before. *

note.p:
The heroine of these verses was an Imagination --
not a Fact. In other words, the effusion was but a
piece of poetical statuary -- a sort of verbal bean
ideal -- designed (to use a figure) for the universal
temple of Feminine Beauty. Not but that I have
seen an actual woman as lovely in person as any
thing I could conceive of the female form by the
most elaborate process of ideal combination. --
But alas! whire was the angel mind, and soul of
love, which should have accompanied "so fair a
piece of well-formed earth"? This otherwise so beauti=
=ful being -- this physical perfection, had never even
dreamt of these!C.H.

div.head: The Forgotten.

lg.l: He shone in the senate, the camp, and the grove,
The minion of Glory, the darling of Love!
He fought for his Country -- the star of the brave!
He died for high Freedom -- the hope of the slave!
And Wisdom and Valor long over him wept;
And Beauty, for ages, strewed flowers where he slept;
And the bards of his People inwrought with their lays
The light of his story, and truth of his praise.
But in Time's dark backward have faded their strains,
And now of his being what record remains? --
Within you lone valley a Tomb crumbles fast,
The name of whose Sleeper is lost in the Past.*

dim recollection of their having been suggested by a
a subtilising effusion of feeling and imagination over
the Outward; the other, a concentration of all external
things, past and present, upon the Inward: and thatthe this address to the Echo is peculiarly of the latter species,
as the Poem immediately preceding it is of the former. --
If I might illustrate this difference by references to the
poetry of others, I would say, that Shelley's classes mostly
with the first kind, and that Byron's comes chiefly under
the head of the last; while that of Milton and Keats is
mainly a blending of both. The ideal complexion of
the one species is green and golden, of the other (or latter)
an intense but cloudy azure; while their blended effect
has its semblance, or outward type, in that of the green
hills and blue waters of the earth, when canopied with
the morning or evening radiance of the heavens.C.H.

lg.l: To cheer my lonely dwelling shed,
Upon its humble roof is heard,
As duly I retire to bed,
A little nightly Bird:
Hark! ever there the creature sings
Its iternat but melodious things
Beneath the silent shining stars,
Or while the moon pays down her light,
Although no wiery thraldom bars
The freedom of its flight,
There nightly thus it ever sings
Its iterant but melodious things.
And while I listen, there will come
Dim memories of the Past, that say
Upon my childhood's happy Home
A little shrilling lay
Was nighty heard, like this which brings
Those iterant but melodious things.
I know not if it were in kind
The same with you peculiar bird,
But on my Father's roof I mind
How often we had heard
A voice like this without which sings
Those iterant but melodious things.
But where is he, the parent Sage
Whose Seven then met his nightly call?
Where him, whose cheek of tenderest age
Was fondest kissed of all?
Asks Sorrow -- while the creature sings
Its iterant but melodious things.
And now too, there's a Grave new made
'Mid scenes to Memory unknown,
And there cold stranger hands have laid
Our manly-hearted Iohn!
I weep -- while still the creature sings
Its iterant but melodious things.
Yet in the memories that steep
Mine eyelids, there's a gentle lore
That brings a balminess to sleep,
And gives me all the more
To love the Creature thus that sings
Its iterant but melodious things.*

note.p:
"We were seven -- and our Family in its earlier years
was pre-eminently a happy one. In fact, I have
never since seen a greater degree of domestic peace and
unity than was presented by my Father's household
for many prosperous years. But Trouble at length
made her abode in our midst -- and a few evil seasons were
enough to break up the foundations of our domestic welfate, and scatter us, some in life and some
in death, over half the world; beginning with Henry our
youngest, who died a child. Then, after a long but fruit
-less struggle in the desolate bye ways of the worldFortune, our
father followed; and latterly our brother Iohn, who
died in early manhood at Seymour, a wild district some-
-where beyond Melbourne, and was shovelled into his lonely
grave (as we learned afterwards) without even a burial service.
Of our youngest living brother, William, -- if he be living, -- who
went to sea, a boy, we have heard little for years: -- and this
is thenearly the whole sum of the past and present fortunes of our Family. --
Such is life -- a fever-dream ending in death.

But should the reader infer from the manner of Iohn
Harpur's burial that he could not have been of any "mark
and likelihood", he would err greviously. He was a man of
fine natural parts; was honest, generous, and brave. But
he lived and died in the Australian Bush, and amongst those
by whom a dead Crichton, if not richly related, whould be
given to the dust "without a stone to mark the spot." I speak
advisedly/ Such would have inevitably have been my own case,
had I have died amongst those with whom I was compelled
to herd during the most intellectual years of my life. Not that such
-a social state is aught to the dead. They are happily beyond
its low thoughted influence. But it perpetuates the brutal-
-ization of the living.C.H. 1847.

l.del: Where Beauty is praising the songs that I sing,
And Pleasure is gushing like brooks in the spring --
From these, and all charming that elswhere I see,
I can turn away, Mary, to think upon thee.
When blasts of affliction blow cold on my rest,
And the pangs that will sleep not in an loud in my breast;
YetStill, however clinging eachmy trouble may be,
I can turn from it, Mary, to think upon thee.
When Weariness sleepeth, and Care is at rest,
And Memory dreameth of all she loves best;
Then as the Moon gazes upon the bright sea,
My Soul, o'er thy dwelling, looks down upon thee.

note.p:
Had I not bought myself to regard the circumstances
which suggested this song, and others of a like character, in the light
of anxious but necessary preparations for my poetical
mission, I should be disposed to mourn that long-
continued and continual waste of feeling of which they are
but the occasional expression, even as one who would not be
comforted.C.H. 1847.

div.head: The Martyrs of Fortune.

lg.l: Want ground the faces of the Prophets old;
Our greatest Bards were only rich in song;
The golden-hearted ever wanted gold;
And they who wronged not ever suffered wrong.
Such, in this unintelligible world,
Seems still the Patriot's, Sage's, Poet's fate;
The mountain of its scornwrong upon them hurled,
Or grinds to misery, or constrains to hate!
To hate sometimes -- but with a perfect will,
To this superior they should ever be:
Though sacrificed, like Iesus, loving still
The injured spirit of Humanity.
For God's beholding patience makes it plain
That so to suffer and to die is gain.*

div.p:
* If the Known were all it would be wholly intelligible.
But this not being the case, the final results of the
whatever is unintelligible must have their solution beyond
it. And as the intelligible is harmonious, so also must
-be the finalities of the unintelligible, through a necessity
-of divine agreement in God's designs, -- binding together
-the Known and the Unknown with the same golden chain
of truth. "Though we are conscious (says Bucke) of the good-
-ness of our Creator, than the meanest soldier
of an army is permitted to know the secrets of his general. Con-
-tinual movements are ordered without any visible design; long
and weary marches are made in the dead of night; fortresses
of little apparent importance are invested; he breaks down
bridges; moves along narrow defiles; animates his troops
at one time, restrains their impatience at another. Wild
and angry conjectures, ceaseless murmurs, innumerable
complaints, are echoed through the camp. The moment,
however, at length arrives. The trumpet sounds; the signal
is given; the charge is made. It is irresistible! The place, the time, and manner having been well chosen. The ranks
of the enemy are broken; thousands join in the pursuit; the
notes of victory sound from hill to hill; murmurs and
conjectures and complaints, all are at an end; the whole
design is cleared up; every one gives himself to joy; every
one celebrates and resounds the praises of his general."
This is a masterly passage; and they who pretend to be
in advance of the position it illustrates, are on the high
road to deception.C.H.

lg.l: Though orbed are thine eyes, like the moon, -- and as bright
As the glad-gushing fountains that flash in her light;
Though thy lips as the core of a cherry may be
That with ripeness hath burst as it hangs on the tree;
Though refulgent thy locks as the tresses that streak
The forehead of morn ere the sun's on the peak;
Though like gardens thy cheek be, whose borders enclose
The delicate lily and exquisite rose; --
Yet, as a sharp thorn in some dew-jewelled bloom
Forbides the fond bee for its nectar to come,
A disdain in thy mien warns each youth to discard
The hope that might foster a tender regard.
Oh, be that but subdued with a generousgracious endeavour,
And the veriest Saint might adore the flower!*

note.p:
The Belle on whom these lines were written (called Beatrice
allegorically) retorted on reading them: "that she would
become all the Poet wished her, on condition of his becoming
the saint who might adore her forever." This was an un=
expected poser. I felt at once that for me to attempt to
put on the saint would be only to put off the attempt;
and that everlasting adoration was just as great a difficulty
spread over a greater surface. So I did nothing but nudge
the Muse, to sing smaller; the end of the affair being, a
lapse of the conditions on both sides, I remaning of the
wicked, and she remaining -- a beautiful shrew.C.H.

div.head:
The New Land Orders.
(1847.)

lg.l: I long did hope the soil of this Clime,
Being to Oligarchial sway,
Was a meet cradle for the birth sublime
Of just Equality at no distant day:
The which, when once its truthful beauty's ray
Maturity shone, should southward draw the prime
Regard o' the world, thence wiser for all time,
And studious more to join the harmonious lay
Of Perfect Freedom perfectly begun:
But now this Hope is shrunk into a Fear!
England's misgovernment its worst hath done
To sow the seed of splendid evil here!
In Sheepshanks we behold a destined peer,
And Oxtail's stockmen shall "my-Lord" his son.*

div.p:
*Should the Squatting System be restricted by no better
Regulations than those deplored in this Sonnet, all the lands
beyond the boundaries will inevitably fall within the grasp of
one class alone -- the great Stockholders, "to them and to their heirs
forever!" and in that event, the national fortune of Australia will
be but a bad copy of the national perditions of Europe. How long
will our shopkeepers and yeomen fail to view this momentous question
in its true light? Can they think that it matters little how, or by
whom, these vast tracts are held, so long as plenty of beef and
wool is grown upon them; is if social progress and the vulgar "go-a-
head" impulse were identical? If so, they err greviously -- and to
the detriment of unborn millions. Besides, a splendid is never a
the detriment of unborn millions. Besides, a splendid is never a
happy land. Immense inequalities in the proprietorships of its
soil are the arch curses of England, giving birth but to two national
monsters, a-- a heartless magnificence in the rich, and a social hope=
lessness in the poor, which become in turn the parents of an au=
-dacious denial in the one class of athe common claims of humanity, and a sullen
distrust even of God's Providence in the other, which "cannot love(it is thought)
the wretch it starves" in the very heart of abundance. Again I say, a splendid is never a happy
land, because wherever there are palaces there are hovels: and this
should determine us in Australia to have as few of either as possi-
-ble. Nay more. Wherever even mansions are very numerous,
and gentlemen in the useless sends of the term exceedingly plentiful,
there also poorhouses abound, there also paupers starve in heaps. Such,
universally, is the condition of England : and our present and future
legislators should perpetually propound to themselves the question,
Whether the same national mockeries -- patrimonial pomp on the one
hand and hereditary destitution on the other -- are to be extended into
Australia? By keeping this constantly at heart, they will assuredly
grow up to something better, and that speedily. And it is the more
urgent upon them to do so, from such an extension of its national
structure being palpably the ulterior design of the Home Government.
But shall it succeed?C.H.

lg.l: The shame of Bondage is upon the Land
Even yet; and a wild cry of Blood complains
To Heaven, like Abel's, wheresoever band
Bushward, the myrmidon's of their selfish gains
Who erst drave Mammon's chariot scourge in hand!
And shall they again, to puff their windy shows
Of aristocracy, horde hither those
Who would perpetuate the shameful brand,
The accusing cry? And this avowedly
To cheapen Freedom? Better that this fair
New world again aone wilderness should be!
Or that the cause of such unrighteous care,
Our cattle, like the swine of Gadara, were
Devil-entered all and drowned in the sea!*

note.p:
No public could have vindicate itself more nobly than did
that of Australia during the agitation of the subject of the above
Sonnet. The base and sordid design of recurring to Transportation,
though originated in the highest places of the land, was shrunk into
an abortion by the strong voice teach the people of Australia for all
time, that they have butto bethus true to themselves, to be able always to
render even a faithless and profligate Legislature, nearly if
not wholly powerless for evil.C.H.

div.head: Iourneying Away.

lg.l: Once, did I only stand in thought beside
The grave of one who for his Country died;
Or on a some spot made holy by the vow
Of tuneful Love, though of an ancient day,
My very life would thrill -- and am I now
Iourneying away
From that fraternal interest which cast
Around me then the feeling of the Past?
I know not -- but no longer thrills my brow,my head hath ceased to leap
Even when, as erst, I voice dame Memory's lay:to the trump of some Homeric lay
Bad progress is it, if from that I'm now I keep
Iourneying away.*

div.p:
* Though our early admiration of whatever is glorious and
beautiful in the humanity of the past, may ever remain intact
within us, yet it soon ceases to act upon our feelings so exquisitely
as at first, or rather our feelings soon cease to react so thrillingly
under it -- and these lines are the expression of this sensational
-decay. I speak in them of the effect that even the imaginary
proximity of the grave of a Hampden (for instance) had once
upon my being; but this Sense of the Past sometimes manifested itself still more
singularly. The circumstance of my only imagining myself the
occupant of a time-worn grave, into which I had fallen, as a pa=
-triot or a martyr, could it also, at that time, make my whole
frame tingle into the very core of its life. But I can now muse
over such matters with marvellous composure. Is the Bard dying
in my bosom?
C.H

div.head: To the Spirit of Poesie.

lg.l: And wilt thou forsake me now,
Poesie -- with Hope together?
Ere this last severest blow
Did lay my struggling Fortunes low,
In love unworn have we not borne
Much wintry weather?
The storm is past (perhaps the last),
Its rainy skirts are wearing over!
But when the sunny time again,
Bridelike, on Life's heart is lain,
Forlorn of thee 'twere nought to me --
A lonely rover!
Ah, misery! what were then my lot
Amongst a race of unbelievers?
Worldly men who all declare
That Gain alone is good and fair,
And they who pore o'er Beauty's lore
Deceived deceivers!
That all the love I've felt emove
Round Fancy, in thy fountain laving,
Move and murmur through the air,
As gathering sweetness everywhere,
The more to bless all Loveliness --
Was Folly craving!
That to believe Mind yet shall weave,
Even though with armed Oppression coping,
A prophet=banner, which unfurled,
Shall herald Freedom through the world,
And teach to man her perfect plan --
Is Folly hoping!
Half at rest upon thy breast
How often have I laid me, musing
That in the golden eventide,
All the dead to Thought allyed
Around me dwelt, unseen yet felt,
Great hopes infusing.
But can it be that all we see,
Feel, think, is but a panorama
Made up of past and present dreams?
That Heaven is vacant as it seems;
And life a breath exhaled by death,
Which ends the drama?
Then is this green and fertile SceneMan's great and ricj Estate
But such as worldlings deem it ever!
Earth and sky, with naught between
Of spiritual life unseen!
And if so, fly! for thou and I
At once should sever.
But there of lives, as Love believes,
All underneath this silent Heaven,
In yon shades and by yon streams,
(As erst I saw them in my dreams)

note.p:
This Poem, I think, will indicate to the philosophical reader,
how painfully I have been sometimes subjected to worldly annoy-
-ance, and how poetically I have struggled at such times, against
the unspiritualising influences obtruded upon me by the sordid
generation of which I am unfortunately a member -- that is,
numerically. Otherwise, I am not of the present men of Austr-
lia; nor could I mass myself down endeavour to do so as I might,
into the dead miry level of their intellectual grossness. I speak
strongly; but if I do so, it is from feeling as strongly how much all that is
immortal in me has been wronged by the society I have been com-
-pelled, through my poverty, herd to herd with, during the best years
of my life.
C.H.

lg.l: Have Faith in God! for surely He
Is good as he is wise and great:
Have Faith -- for here or elsewhere, we
Shall prove the harmony of Fate!
Though storms the depths of Life up toss --
Though breakers strew its shores with loss,
And Love be slain by Hate,
Believe that Evil understood,
Were but the shadowy test of still prevailing Good.
That this is worthy of belief
The heart-thrill it creates declares:
The holy calm it brings to Grief --
The promises, like heavenly airs,
It breathes into the soul, to fill
The failing music of the will,
When broken by despairs;
Till, touche as with Apollo's rod,
Even Death's the bard of Hope -- O, then have Faith in God!
Have Faith in Man! for with a mind
More roomy than the world; a heart
That opened by true love of kind;
Might inexhaustibly impart;
He yet -- even he, though erring long,
From the dark spells of ancient wrong
Shall, like a dreamer, start!
With all-atoning heed to scan
The ways of Love and Truth: -- have faith in God and Man.
Such was the language of my Lyre,
As high on Kobanonia's bald
And craggy top, mine heart did fire
With ardours from the Past recalled;
Ere the world's warfare might prevail
O'er life's first hopes -- alas, too frail,
Too easily appalled!
But on such altar was it vain
To pray for that large trust in God and Man again?*

note.p:
As an implicit belief in God's goodness is the fountain head
of all true religion, so a large faith in the capacity of human
nature for good, is the root of all genuine morality. To think
nobly of our original is to respect ourselves, and thence come chastity
honor and fortitude; while to believe it radically incapable and
vile, is to live and die (speaking universally). on a level with this degrading estimate. It
may be true -- it is true, that man, the individual, is often desperate=
=ly wicked. Communities also, may be mostly corrupt, selfish, un-
-principled, and inhuman. Still the surviving sense of man-
-kind, as to right and wrong, and glory and shame, is unfail-
-ingly just in the end. In the darkest ages -- in the most
virtuous societies, there have always sprung up a few faithful
soldiers of God and Humanity, as ready to die as to live in the
cause of the Intellectual Liberty, which comprehends the interests of all
Truth: and this proves sufficiently -- that our capacities for good
are primordiate and fundamental in the race; whereas our
tendencies to evil, however obstinate and prevailing,

div.head: To a Lady,
div.p:
On hearing that she remarked, while censuring
certain slips in the Author's conduct, that "they
would not be at all mindable if his circumstances were
independent."

lg.l: Though, Lady fair, thy judgment's more
Than generally lenient,
I'm irked to find its moral lore
So mightily convenient.
My slips, it seems, fill Censure's throat
With proverbs sage as musty,
Only because I fill a coat
That looketh somewhat rusty.
But though, when such its referenceso 'tis governed, I
May only smile at censure,
Henceforth, in self defence, I'll try

lg.l: To make my life more pence-sure:
Or pocket-virtuous, if the phrase
May better give my meaning:
And gain, by patching thus my ways,
The "one thing-needful" charm forart at of Mammon's 'well done' for screening.*

note.p:
Men's acts are judged of by society upon grounds al
-together too positional. Of course our outward circum-
-stances should determine the amount of good or evil in
particular acts, but not to the extent of making what is
almost a virtue on one individual a vice in another.
In a declaration of setiment, for instance, what would
be held the height of imprudence, if nothing worse, in a poor
man, is often for an evidence of spirit and generosity
in a wealthy one. Now this is pernicious, and clearly
indicates that the present structure of society is miscalculated
to give fair play to that bold individuality of character which
best constitutes its moral harmony.C.H>

On receiving the above note I would add a few
words to it. I am no apologist
for vice in any, myself
included. At this moment, I am thankful to Providence, for
all that I may have suffered fromfor past misconduct. Still I
affirm that society in censuring me at all, while it over
looked the same faulty in others, on purely position at con-
-siderations, was acting meanly, and in a manner only
calculated to draw upon itself the contempt and enmity of
nine out of every ten delinquents who should make the
same observation under the same circumstances. Even open
profligacy is not the parent of so vile a brood of social
evils as is a pretendedly God fearing Mammom-worship.
Even the self-declared villain may have something noble
remaining in him; but he who has once systematically
arrayed himself in the conveniences of Pretence, is
thenceforth ingrainially ignoble forever.C.H.

div.head:
The Tree of Liberty.
[A Song for the Future.]

lg.l: Wll plant the Tree of Liberty
In the centre of the Land,
And round it ranged as guardians be
A vowed and trusty band;
And sages bold and mighty souled
Shall dress it day by day --
But more unto the traitor who
Whould break one branch away!
Then sing the Tree of Liberty
For the vow that we have made!
May it so flourish, that when we
Are buried in its shade,
Fair Womanhood and Love and Good,
All pilgrims pure, shall go,
Its growth to bless for happiness --
O may it flourish so.
Till felled by gold, as bards have told,
In the Old World once it grew;
But then we know its fruits were sold,
And only to the Few!
But here at last, whate'er his caste,
Each man at Nature's call,
Shall pluck as well what none may sell --
The fruit that blooms for All.
The sing the Tree of Liberty,
And the men who shall defend
Its glorious future, towering free
For this all-righteous end:
That happiness a world to bless
From its full growth should grow --
Our Southern Tree of Liberty
Shall flourish even so.*

note.p:
I call this Poem a Song for the Future, because, though utterly a republican in politics, I yet believe it will be best
for my Country to continue during the present century
at least, a part of the British Monarchy. For even the
state-botches of Downing Street are full fifty years in
advance of our half-educated wool kings; and such Gov-
-ernments therefore, as they may from time to time fabri-
-cate for us, though on the most threadbare models, will
latter could or would tinker up in the event of a
premature separation.C.H.

div.head:
The March of Knowledge.
[A War-song for the Nineteenth Century.]

lg.l: The March of Knowledge hasten!
Charge onward and be free!
Before are Mercy, Iustice, Truth,
Our standard bearers three!
Heed not the threat of hirelings --
Be bold in deed and word --
But spare to use the murderous gun,
Nor meddle with the sword.
O fought we for the despot --
To plunder -- not to save!
To surfeit dungeons with the good --
The eloquent -- the brave!
With patriot blood to redden
The violated Lands! --
Outstanding from the twilight of his days
In bold relief, he takes the student's gaze;
As some grey-crumbling Abbey glooms sublime
A failing wonder to a later time.
And one so spiritual for his age,
And studiously happy in the sage
Sweet mystery of Rhyme, most surely claims
High mention on the roll of Everlasting Names.
A well of English undefiled is he,
Say scholiasts, -- ever brimming over bounteously!
But what most happy takes me while I spell him o'er,
Is am all-hearty love of mental lore,
Together with a crowing, frank delight
In primal Nature's beautiful and bright
Yet daily objects; -- for it is the creed
I ever carry with me when I read,
That whoso had for these beloving eyes
Was more than commonly both pure and wise; --
Was one in whom an earnest joy in Good
More than redeemed the errors of his blood --
Was stored in spirit with a portion rich
Of that transcendent seraphism, which
Of all things most, designed to intimate
Man's elevation from the brute's estate,
Declares the music of his life to be
Something that cannot perish utterly:
But virtual in the world's prime features still,
(Sun, moon, and stars; clear stream, and vernal hill)
An effluence that the Present with the Past
Connects transfusedly -- and which, at last,
May constitute Humanity a whole,

On-flowing through all time -- one mighty Stream
of Soul.*

note.p:
I will append by way of Note to this criticism an ex-
-quisite bit of prose from the pen of an American Poet,
(Lowell.) "There is in him the exuberant freshness and
greenness of Spring. Everything he touches leaps into
full blossom. His gladness and humour and pathos
are inepressible as a fountain. Dam them with a
prosaic subject, and they will overleap it in a sparkling
cascade that times even the hindrance to a beauty-
Choke them with a tedious theological disquisition,
and they bubble up forthwith all around it with a
delightful gurgle.xxx Reading him is like
brushing through the dewy glades at sunrise; every
thing is new and sparkling and fragrant." -- There
is a bright bubbling bead of beauty upon every word
of this passage. For freshness of thought and felicity
of expression it could hardly be surpassed.C.H..

lg.l: Standing alone, a study in itself,
How Shakspeare's Volume glorifies my shelf!
Sphered in the light of his creative mind,
A world of wonder, shadowing this, we find.
Lean fatal Hags ride posting on the blast,
And wing'd Immortals throng around us fast;
These of a silken loveliness that glows
Like the dim beauty of a moonlit rose,
As firmly lined as sculptured iron those.
Lo, now futurity uplifts her veil,
And pours her Phantom Kings before the tyrant pale!
Now in the moon's quick glimpses gleaming cold,
A shadow warrior's stalking Form behold!
Whilst o'er, like echoes from oblivion's coast,
Comes the deep speech of the unquiet Ghost.
Turn we a page -- O for a power to save
The meek mad Beauty from her timeless grave!
"Sweets to the sweet", with the sad Queen we cry,
And dash the sacred tear-drop from our eye.
But seek we surer knowledge, paven hard
With such stern precepts as grey minds regard;
Or such as breathing the soul's fervour, primes
Our piety, and our moral faith sublimes;
How many a thoughtful page is shared between
Fancy, and prudence in her sagest mien,
And that high wisdom which informs us still,
Heaven "shapes our ends rough-hew them how we will;"
And that, though vain and erring, Human Nature
Is yet a mystery of angelic feature,
And godlike in its spiritual stature.
Thus constantly some vital Moral shines
ike sunlight, in the current of his lines.
Ambition's worshipper, in Caesar's death,
May see how mortal is mere glory's breath;
And learn from Richard's spectre-haunted hour,
To hate the hideousness of godless power.
What sensations, while thunders loud the page
With falling Antony's majestic rage,
But must, with profit to himself, deplore
The falal witcheries of the regal whore!
What wealthy prodigal from Timon's fall
Shall aim not to escape the flatterer's thrall?
Nor scorn, as then indignantly he starts,
The heartlessness of fashionable hearts?
What magisterial tyrant but shall fear,
Through Angelo, to be less righteous than severe?
What husband viewing dark Othello's deed,
But shall with caution, at the worst, proceed?
The sire may learn to shun the rivalous hate
That consummated gentle Iuliett's fate;
The child be chastened by the filial tear
Shed for the wrongs that maddened royal Lear.
Now with desire of laughter are we bit?
Let's roar with Falstaff in a storm of wit
If fierce our mood, -- another leaf will yield
Meet rage, the thunders of a battle field!
To innocence would we devote awhile?
Miranda beckons from her magic isle.
With injured virtue would we mingle tears?
A Katherine, or Hermione, appears.
Would we condole with lonely love? O then,
Behold, -- a mortal angel, -- Imogen.
With joyous goodness thirst we to rejoice?
Belmont is vocal with its Portia's voice.
Would we be spiced with lady-wit? I wis
One bee-like stinging, yet most honeyed kiss
Of bright frank Beatrice, if we've grace to snatch it,
Shall make us Benedicts -- and lo, we catch it!
Comes o'er us, like a long remembered strain,
The love of groves we ne'er may know again?
In shady Arden then let's wander wild
With buoyant Rosalind and Celia mild;
Or with the melancholy Iaques complain,
How blind is Fortune, yet how worthless Gain; --
Gain or of gold or glory -- both a jest!
Or power -- a solemn mockery at best!
Then wander on in thought, to join afar
Those princely revellers in green Navarre;
Taking, for joy's completeness, in our way
The shepherd-feast that glads Bohemia,
To talk with Perdita of flowers, -- from whose
Rich warbled words, as from a shower of dews,
They borrow fresher scents and still diviner hues.
Would we be solaced with a song? Sweet lays
That breathe the innocence of ancient days,
Like drops of gold and gems of rarest hue,
Are interspersed the glorious Volume through.
How oft, when wandering in the woods away,
As goldenly around me closed the day,
And musing thus upon each Scene I'd read --
How often to my listening heart I've said:
While "sweetest Shakspeare, Fancy's (darling) child,
Warbles (for me) his native woodnotes wild,"
Let others strive for wealth and power, and dwell
In costly mansions -- I can spare them well.

note.p:
For more than a year of my youth, Shakspeare was
nearly my whole reading -- was, in fact (and luckily) almost
the only book my means could at that time command. At first
I perused him rapidly right through, in order to take in
at one mighty draught his entire spirit. Then I repe-
-rused him with minute attention, -- that is, critically; un-
-derlining every beauty I could perceive, even to a felicity
of phrase. I next reconsidered the whole, transcribing as
I proceeded, almost all that I had previously underlined.
After this, I again read him attentively through, with an
eye to the punctuation alone; and yet again for the sole
purpose of testing the progressive steps in his versification.
From this last reading, if I recollect aright, I came to
the conclusions, that all his British historical Plays, with
the exceptions of Henry VIII., Cymbeline, and Macbeth, were
amonsgt his earliest productions; and that his Roman
Plays, Hamlet and Othello, with all his Comedies, except the
Comedy of Errors, the Two Gentlemen of Verona, Romeo and Iuliet,
and another or two, ranged subsequently, -- with the Tempest
last; in which his blank verse is quite as interflowing as Milton's,
though, of course, somewhat looser and less measured.

Of the style of these Critical Rhymes, I will remark and of all of my poems of a like kind
here, once for all, that though I have avoided in them the pre-
-cise couplet balance of Pope, as a mere mellefluous monotony,
I have yet considered that something of such a balance should
be maintained, upon the whole, in our regular heroic rhyme;
believing moreover, that a certain blank-verse-rhymed style,
(if I may coin the expressiona term for it) now much in vogue, is just
such a failure as might be expected to follow from the meeting
of extremes, however strikingly it may indicate (as it does)
the prior existence of an opposite abuse.C.H.

lg.l: In this what a grave beauty claims our praise,
Through the long march of his stupendous Lays.
How full -- how fit the epithets; how terse
Each phrase, as built into the solid verse.
Then in his management of tune and time
How richly can we spare the oil of rhyme.
What melody of measures; flowing still
Into one lengthened harmony -- until
Some fine, up-rolling redundancy shall fill
(Even like a heaping wave when surging near)
With doubled thunder the astonished ear!
Which thence more soothable, is soothed once more
By cadences as silvery as before.
Such graces these of Style, that wanting such,
Even true poesie will lack too much.
But of his "stiffness" what made Iohnson bawl,
So that the charge is grown proverbial?
A rigid narrowness of taste, combined
With a tripodic tunelessness of mind,
That just a see-saw couplet's limbs could scan,
Filed up and jingled on the Grub-street plan;
Or a spruce quatrain, alternating nice --
But not the numerous peals of the Lost Paradise!
For these, indeed, he had nor ear nor soul,
He could not mete their interflowing roll
Each being (try them, all who yet may doubt)
A piece of "linked sweetness long drawn out."
As through some stream's most christal purity,
The virgin gold is seen below, we see

With all the visionary affluence
That tempered the stern grandeur of his sense.
Then in his Carol for the Virgin's Son,
Toned like a trumpet for some victory won
Amid the wondering Shepherds placed, we mark
Descending, Heaven's high heraldry descend -- and hark!
While burning choirs, in star-like clusters, gem
The midnight gloom that shroudeth Bethlehem,
How swelling up in utterance divine,
Their tidings peal through each triumphant line!
The theme is changed: wild lamentation loads
The car of Doom; for now the Infernal Gods
From their pontific thrones suddenly hurled,
Forego, despairing, the re-conquered world!
And hellward all, in the tumultuous verse,
Like far-off thunders heavily disperse.
With Melancholy then, how sweet to rove,
Whilst the wild moon seems wandering lost above,
'Mid clouds that like drear woods and mountains grey
Blind up the track of her accustomed way;
And hear in spirit out footstep's solemn beat

And till the sun "drops in the western bay."
Then, for relief, let Fancy woo such dreams
As to his youth were known, by haunted streams
Sleeping, -- till music, like the soul of Love,
Came breathing from some Nymph-concealing grove;--
Or joyously upstarting, she is free
To dance o'er the green earth with glad Euphrosyne!
Jest in her train with him who Care derides,
And laught with Laughter, "holding both his sides."*

lg.l: A prim, complacently poetic wight,
Smooth in his style, and in his matter light.
He lived in Milton's day, more landed far

With principles as sliding as his rhymes,

This is hardly giving him all his due. He wrote many

and character is correct in the main -- asis far as it goes. His
fashionable tact alone, would be conclusive to my mind of

greatness, because it would inevitably lead him to affect

lg.l: Refinement's Bard! my study when a boy --
The healthful source of many a polished joy!
What though some moderns mystically sage
In Metaphysics, who, their critic rage
Imbibe, I fear me, from the Nighmare's dugs, --
And thence are stickelrs for such wonder-bugs
As troubled Coleridge in his flightiest days,
And Wordsworth when he wrote his "lyric" lays; --
Though such, thus crudely literate, refuse
His soul the deeper insights of the Muse;
And granting learning and a taste refined,
Deny him native amplitude of mind:
To such I answer -- That, as to the eyes
Perfect proportion ever softens size,
The Bard's conceptions will not seem immense
Where all is ease, propriety, and sense,
Though such in fact; -- and that the present case
Is strictly thus, all see who have the grace.
But they, with the wild German mama bit,
Take big disorder for the prime of wit,
And barbarised, with Gothic tongues abuse
The classic structures of a judging Muse.
But let such cavilthough let -- cavil as they willtill then tired --
Little Dan Pope was a great Poet still
Though I admit, his models are notEven though his poems be not models such
As Keats-like spirits should be bound by much;
Nor yet his style of thought the proper guage
Wherewith to sound a Wordsworth's nervous rage,
Or test the fancy, voluve and free,
Of Hunt, -- or Coleridge's wierd ecstasy.

lg.l: What silver peals of music here are rung!
What pearls of fancy in what order strung
On golden lines that fuse and stream upon the tongue!
How smiling is the satire! and the wit
How forceable, and yet how exquisite!
What gay creations, too, enlarge the theme,
And "bask and whiten" in the Poet's dream!
As silken blossoms waving on then sprays,
All dewy, glint in Cynthia'sthe Moon's mystic rays;
As silver mists upon the mountains born,
Flit in the first white glances of the Morn.
Most finished Lay! like (in bright semblance seen)
The bridal mantle of some Eastern Queen,
All starred with gems of price, and figured through
With inwrought beauty, -- such as, in his view
Of Paradise, the Prophet saw employ
The daughters of imperishable joyIoy
In this supreme! with what a Iove-like ease
He crushed the Titans of the times' disease!
"Bared the mean heart that lurked beneath a star!"
And even with brazen Dulness waged victorious war.
O, could I wield so well, in moderncurrent song,
The searching scourge of the sateric thong,
How the bold visaged Vices of the day
Should crouch, and slink like beaten curs, away!
But chief, the Lust of Gold, that hell-lit rage
Which eats into the Spirit of the age!
That Mammon-worship which makes outward show
The prime morality wherever we go!
Befrills Religion like a jade in vogue!
Besaints a usurer -- if a "pious" rogue!
Enslaves even Iustice, till she dare not see
In its high places palpable villainy!
Brands honest povertyNeed with shame! and, vaintill moneyed Hate
Its christian beauty, dubs philanthropy insane in a poor estate!
Impairs in souls once elevate and brave,
All noble scorn of every prosperous knave!
Taints even the heart of childhood! and distils
A social poison that all friendship kills! --
O, I would lash it to its native hell,
With Devils thenceforth not with Men, to dwell.*
